H0.text: Millions of years ago, Antarctica was in a warmer location on Earth is the conclusion best supported by the fossil evidence of tropical fern plants discovered in Antarctica, a continent at Earth's south pole that no longer supports those plants.

H1.text: Recently, a natural disaster killed all of the fern plants in Antarctica is the conclusion that the fossil evidence of tropical fern plants found in Antarctica—despite the fact that these plants do not currently grow there—most supports.

H2.text: Recently, birds stopped carrying the seeds of fern plants to Antarctica, a conclusion best supported by the fossil evidence of tropical fern plants found in Antarctica even though those plants no longer grow there today.

H3.text: Millions of years ago, Earth's south pole was much colder than it is today is the conclusion supported by the fossil evidence of tropical fern plants discovered in Antarctica, a continent at Earth's south pole that no longer supports those plants.

A4.text: In the Cretaceous, Antarctica was dominated by a fern-conifer ecosystem, which changed into a temperate rainforest by the end of that period.

A5.text: East Antarctica was at the equator, where seafloor invertebrates and trilobites flourished in the tropical seas.
